src:
Qantas hentikan operasi satu pesawat Boeing 737 NG karena ada 'retakan'
03 Nov 2019, 08:08 by Afrizal Aziz


Qantas hentikan operasi satu pesawat Boeing 737 NG karena ada 'retakan'

KBRN, : Perusahaan penerbangan ini menyatakan beberapa maskapai memeriksa pesawat 737 NG mereka sesudah Boeing mengungkapkan adanya bagian pesawat yang rentan terhadap retakan.Kantor berita AFP melaporkan sebanyak 50 pesawat jenis ini di seluruh dunia telah berhenti beroperasi disebabkan masalah tersebut.Qantas mengatakan: "Retakan itu memang ada, tetapi ini tidak berarti membahayakan keselamatan pesawat.""Namun kami tak akan menerbangkan pesawat kecuali memang sepenuhnya aman."Boeing mengatakan retakan itu ditemukan di daerah "garpu acar" - bagian dari pesawat yang melekatkan sayap ke badan pesawat.Bulan lalu, pihak pengawas penerbangan Amerika Serikat memerintahkan pengecekan seluruh pesawat 737 NG yang telah menempuh lebih dari 30.000 kali penerbangan.Qantas menyatakan tak ada pesawat 737 NG mereka yang telah terbang lebih dari 30.000 kali. Mereka menambahkan pesawat yang ditemukan mengalami retakan baru menempuh perjalanan kurang dari 27.000 kali.Seri 737 NG ini adalah pendahulu dari seri 737 Max.Masalah ini datang sesudah Boeing dipaksa untuk menghentikan operasi pesawat mereka yang lebih baru, 737 Max, menyusul dua kecelakaan yang menelan banyak korban jiwa.Hari Rabu (30/10) Direktur Utama Boeing Dennis Muilenburg menyatakan kepada parlemen Amerika Serikat bahwa perusahaannya telah membuat kekeliruan terkait pesawat 737 Max. Pihak parlemen menuduh Boeing telah memburu-buru agar proses persetujuan bisa segera diberikan.Qantas meyatakan mereka akan memeriksa 33 pesawat dalam armada penerbangan mereka hari Jumat (31/10). Mereka tidak merespons laporan yang menyebutkan bahwa sudah ditemukan pesawat kedua yang juga mengalami retakan di tempat yang sama.Sebuah serikat penerbangan Australia, The Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association, menyerukan kepada Qantas agar menghentikan seluruh operasi 737 NG mereka, dan seruan ini ditolak oleh Qantas karena dianggap sebagai "reaksi berlebihan".Maskapai Amerika Serikat Southwest Airlines baru-baru ini juga menemukan retakan di salah satu pesawat Boeing 737 NG mereka.(BBC)
text:
Qantas has stopped operating one Boeing 737 NG aircraft because there is a 'crack'
03 Nov 2019, 08:08 by Afrizal Aziz


Qantas has stopped operating one Boeing 737 NG aircraft because there is a 'crack'

KBRN: The airline said several airlines were checking their 737 NG planes after Boeing revealed parts of the aircraft were vulnerable to cracks. AFP news agency reported that as many as 50 aircraft of this type worldwide had stopped operating due to the problem. Qantas said: "The cracks It does exist, but this does not mean jeopardizing the safety of the aircraft. "" But we will not fly the aircraft unless it is completely safe. "Boeing said the crack was found in the" pickle fork "area - the part of the plane that attaches wings to the fuselage. Last month, the United States flight inspector ordered the inspection of all 737 NG aircraft that had traveled more than 30,000 times. Qasas said no 737 NG aircraft had flown more than 30,000 times. They added that the aircraft found to have had new cracks traveled less than 27,000 times. The 737 NG series was the predecessor to the 737 Max series. This problem came after Boeing was forced to stop operating their newer aircraft, the 737 Max, following two accidents that swallowed many fatalities. Wednesday (30/10) Boeing Managing Director Dennis Muilenburg told the United States parliament that his company had made a mistake with the 737 Max. Parliament has accused Boeing of rushing it so that the approval process can be immediately granted. Qantas said they would inspect 33 aircraft in their flight fleet on Friday (31/10). They did not respond to reports stating that a second aircraft had also been found to have cracks in the same place. An Australian aviation union, The Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association, called on Qantas to stop all their 737 NG operations, and this call was rejected by Qantas because considered an "overreaction". The US airline Southwest Airlines recently also found a crack in one of their Boeing 737 NG aircraft. (BBC)
